bad.work: Illustrations to Milton's L'Allegro and Il Penseroso

Illustrations to Milton's "L'Allegro" and "Il Penseroso" Copy 1 : electronic
edition

filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of Blake's
twelve water-color illustrations to John Milton's poems "L'Allegro" and "Il Penseroso,"
now in the Pierpont Morgan Library, New York. These splendid designs are published in
our new Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image
Search and Inote (our image annotation program). Each design is accompanied by a
manuscript leaf that includes a quotation of the lines illustrated and brief
interpretive comments by Blake. These manuscript leaves are also reproduced here in
sequence following each design.
Produced for Blake's chief patron, Thomas
Butts, c. 1816-20, the "L'Allegro" and "Il Penseroso" illustrations exhibit the delicacy
and refinement typical of Blake's late water-color style. Milton's contrasting companion
poems gave Blake yet another opportunity to explore his own sense of contrariety, much
as he did earlier in his career in Songs of Innocence and of
Experience. Through the careful selection of passages to illustrate, Blake also
emphasizes the visionary and transformative moments in Milton's poems.
At
present the Archive contains 45 copies of 18 of Blake's 19 illuminated books (all fully
searchable); the Thomas Butts set of Blake's water colors illustrating the Book of Job,
also in the Pierpont Morgan Library; and now the first of several series of Milton
illustrations that we will be adding in Preview. In the near future we expect to release
more drawings and prints in Preview, a much-anticipated electronic edition of Jerusalem Copy E, and further supplementary materials, including a
biography and glossary.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site,
imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made
possible through the continuing support of the Institute for Advanced Technology in the
Humanities at the University of Virginia, by a major grant from the Preservation and
Access Division of the National Endowment for the Humanities, by the University of North
Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries
and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their
collections in the Archive.

objdescid.note:
The designs were first owned, and probably commissioned, by Thomas Butts, but we
have no records about their date of composition. The range of dates is based on the
1816 watermarks and on stylistic features. The accompanying manuscript leaves bearing
pen and ink quotations from "L'Allegro" and "Il Penseroso," as well as brief
descriptions by Blake, were very probably written at about the same time.

objinfo.objsize: approximately 16.0 x 12.0 cm. (the water colors); approximately 16.5 x 12.0 cm. (the manuscript leaves)
objinfo.note:
Each design is accompanied by a separate sheet of paper. These bear, on their
rectos, pen and ink quotations from the poem illustrated by the accompanying design
and descriptive comments by Blake. Both types of inscription are in Blake's hand. The
versos of these separate sheets bear brief title inscriptions, also written by Blake
in pen and ink. The versos are affixed to backing sheets. The verso inscriptions can
be seen with a strong backing light, but they cannot be photographed.
objinfo.leafsize: approximately 16.0 x 12.0 cm. (the water colors); approximately 16.5 x 12.0cm. (the manuscript leaves)
objinfo.note:
The leaves of the water colors appear to have been trimmed, at least very
slightly, on their margins.
objinfo.medium: water color, with pen and ink drawing; pen and ink manuscript
objinfo.support: wove paper (the water colors); laid paper (the manuscript leaves)
objinfo.watermark: Objects 1, 3, 11, 17, 19, and 23 (water colors 1, 2, 6, 9, 10, 12) show a watermark, "M & J LAY 1816."

provenance.name: Morgan Library and Museum
provenance.note: Thomas Butts c. 1816-20; by inheritance to Thomas Butts, Jr., who sold the water colors at a Foster's auction in London, 29 June 1853, lot 99 (£7.7s to Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Lord Houghton); by inheritance to Milnes' son, 1st Marquess of Crewe; sold Sotheby's London, 30 March 1903, lot 1 (1960 to A. Jackson, probably a dealer acting for Perry); Marsden J. Perry by 1905; probably sold c. 1906-07 to William A. White; by inheritance to Alfred T. White in 1907; by inheritance to A. T. White's daughter, Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen, by 1926; sold by Adrian Van Sinderen to the Pierpont Morgan Library in December 1949.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
The female personification of Mirth stands in the center of the design,
surrounded by at least twenty-two other figures. Her hair is long and curly, and
she wears a crown or wreath of small berries or flowers. She smiles and looks out
toward the viewer. A halo or possibly a small cloud surrounds her head. At least
three spirits appear above and to the left of Mirth's head within the halo or
cloud structure. The second figure from the bottom may be seen from behind with
its right leg partly drawn up. A fourth indistinct figure may appear to the right. A
female nymph—possibly representing the personification of
Liberty—stands or hovers in the lower left portion of the design. She is gowned and
may be wearing leggings or stockings. A quiver containing at
least two arrows hangs by a strap over her left shoulder. With her right hand she
grasps the feathered tail of an arrow; she also holds hands with (or at least touches the hand of) Mirth. A male spirit stands or hovers just to the left of the central figure, wearing short
breeches or tights and a shirt with an elaborate, ruffled collar. Two gowned,
female nymphs stand or hover to the right of Mirth. The figure closest to Mirth bends her
arms upwards above her head; the figure to the right has her arms bent with the
palms held out at shoulder-height. The ground below the figures is govered with
grass. Leafy vegetation appears in the lower left corner of the
design; this may represent distant trees. Regtangular shapes in the lower left
corner of the image suggest a distant building or buildings. Additional shapes in
the lower right may represent a city, including triangular spires. A distant
mountain rises above the city in the lower right corner of the design. A female
nymph flies or hovers near the right border of the design. The figure is gowned
with bat-like wings surrounding her head, torso, and upper legs. A male
spirit—possibly representing Milton's "wrinkled Care"—flies or
hovers near the right border of the design. The figure has two horns on his head
and is seen in a contracted position with his arms crossed and his left knee
raised to his chest. The figure wears an expression of anger or disapproval. A
nude male spirit hovers or flies to the right of the central figure. His arms are
bent with his hands grasping his sides; he is smiling and likely represents
Milton's "Laughter." Three nude spirits fly or hover above the figure of Laughter.
The largest figure in the group has its legs spread and arms raised horizontally;
its head is bent back and turned to the left. A nude spirit flies or hovers above
and to the left of Mirth's raised left hand; it plays a long trumpet or musical horn held in its extended
right hand. Three circles, possibly bubbles, appear in the upper right corner of the design,
to the right of the trumpet. Below, a nude female(?) spirit flies or hovers with
her arms bent upward; she is seen from behind. A gowned spirit flies or hovers to
the right; the figure faces left with his or her body horizontal. The figure's
arms are bent with the palms turned up. Five female spirits appear above and to
the left of the central figure of Mirth; they are likely flying or hovering, but
may also rest on a small band of clouds. The central figure of the group flies
diagonally downward and to the left. Her arms are extended down and to the left;
she points with both hands towards the gowned male spirit below. The gowned male
flies or hovers to the left of Mirth. He is seen from behind with his lower body facing left; his
torso and head are twisted to the right. His head is bent back and he looks up and
slightly to the right towards the female figures above. Yellow and red washes in
the lower half of the design suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc:
The female personification of Mirth stands or hovers in the center of the
design, surrounded by at least twenty-three other figures. She faces forward
and wears a transparent gown with her breasts clearly visible. Her hair is long
and curly, and she wears a crown or wreath of small berries or flowers. She
smiles and looks out toward the viewer. A halo or possibly a small cloud
surrounds her head. The figure stands or hovers with her right foot on tiptoe; her left
leg is bent and her left foot is raised above the ground. She may be dancing.
Both arms are bent slightly. Her left arm is raised at approximately 135
degrees with the palm turned out toward the viewer. Her right arm is raised at
approximately 45 degrees; she holds (or at least touches) hands with the figure furthest to the
left. The fingers of both hands are slightly spread.

A female nymph—possibly representing the personification of
Liberty—appears in the lower left portion of the design. She stands or hovers
with her left foot on tiptoe and her right foot raised off the ground; her body
leans or arches to the left, and she may be dancing. Her head is turned back to
the right. Her eyes are raised and she looks toward Mirth, above and to the
right. She is gowned. A few lines on her lower left leg and foot suggest that she may be wearing leggings or stockings of some sort. A quiver containing at least two arrows hangs by a strap over her left
shoulder. Her arms are bent upward with her hands raised above her head. Her
right palm is turned down, and she holds the feathered tail of an arrow in her
right hand. Her left hand is held vertically; she holds hands hands with
Mirth.

A male spirit stands or hovers just to the left of Mirth.
The figure faces forward with his head turned to the right. He has short, curly hair. The figure wears short breeches or tights and a shirt
with an elaborate, ruffled collar. He stands with his right foot
raised on tiptoe and left leg drawn up; he may be dancing. The figure's
arms are bent upward with the palms held vertically and the fingers
spread.

A gowned female nymph with short, curly hair stands or hovers to the right of
Mirth. She stands with her left foot on tiptoe and her right leg bent and
raised off the ground; she may be dancing. The figure's arms are bent upwards
with her hands above her head and her fingers spread. Her body faces forward and to the
right, but her head is turned slightly to the left. She may look left towards
Mirth. The figure appears to be smiling.

A gowned female nymph stands or hovers in the lower right corner of the
design. Her right foot is on tiptoe and her left foot is raised above the
ground; her body leans to the right, and she may be dancing. The figure's arms
are bent upward with her hands raised at shoulder-height and her palms turned
outward, fingers slightly spread. Her head is raised slightly and she appears to be
smiling.

A female nymph flies or hovers near the right border of the design.
The figure is gowned and appears to have bat-like wings surrounding her head, torso,
and upper legs. Her body is twisted and her upper body bends to the left. The
figure's right arm is raised vertically above her head with the palm held
vertically and fingers spread. Her left arm is bent below her chest with the
hand turned upside down and the palm vertical. Her head is turned to the right;
she may look towards the horned figure above and to the right.

A male spirit—possibly representing Milton's "wrinkled
Care"—flies or hovers near the right border of the design. The figure
has two horns on his head, and so may possibly be a devil. He may also be bald.
He faces forward and is seen in a contracted position with his arms crossed and
his left knee raised to his chest. One arm with palm up, or possibly even his right leg, is extended above his head. The figure
wears an expression of anger or disapproval. An abraded area on and above the figure's head may obscure some small motifs.

A nude male spirit hovers or flies to the right of Mirth. He is
smiling and likely represents Milton's "Laughter." His hair is short and curly.
The spirit's head may rest on his right shoulder. His eyes are raised and he
looks left towards Mirth. His arms are bent and he holds his sides with both
hands. His body is twisted so that his pelvis faces slghtly up. The figure's
legs are bent back and spread apart.

Three nude spirits fly or hover above the figure of Laughter. The
largest figure of the group faces right with his or her head bent back and to
the left. The figure's legs are spread and its arms are raised horizontally.
The body of the figure to the right is horizontal. The figure below may be seen
from behind.

A gowned spirit flies or hovers in the upper right corner of the
design. The figure faces left with his or her body horizontal. The figure's
arms appear to be wrapped around his or her chest. An object dangling below the arms may be a bundle of some sort.

A nude female(?) spirit flies or hovers to the right of Mirth's
raised left hand. The figure is seen from behind with clearly visible buttocks.
The spirit's arms are bent upward, and the fingers on her right hand may be
spread. The figure faces away, with her head turned slightly to the right. Her
hair may be drawn back in a bun.

A nude spirit flies or hovers above and to the left of Mirth's
raised left hand. The figure is seen from behind and bends to the right. The
spirit's right leg is extened and its left leg is bent. The figure's right arm
is raised horizontally and is extended to the right. The spirit holds and plays
a long trumpet or musical horn; the spirit's left arm is not
pictured.

Three circles, possibly bubbles, appear in the upper right corner of the design, to the
right of the trumpet.

Five female spirits appear above and to the left of the central
figure of Mirth. They are likely flying or hovering, but may also rest on a
small band of clouds. The spirit upper left faces forward and may have her
hair pulled into a bun. Only the figure's upper body is visible. She is smiling
and may be gowned. Her right hand is raised to the left of her breast with the
palm turned out towards the viewer.

Five female spirits appear above and to the left of the central
figure of Mirth. They are likely flying or hovering, but may also rest on a
small band of clouds. The spirit second from the left (just above the lowest figure in the group) faces left with her head
turned down and to the right; she may be looking toward Mirth. Only her upper
body is visible. The figure is gowned and has long hair. Her mouth is slightly open and
she appears to be smiling. The figure's arms are bent with the palms turned out
toward the viewer.

Five female spirits appear above and to the left of the central
figure of Mirth. They are likely flying or hovering, but may also rest on a
small band of clouds. The lowest spirit flies diagonally downward
and to the left with her head bent up and to the right. Her eyes are raised and
she likely looks toward the spirit above. Her mouth is open and she appears to
be smiling. The figure is gowned and has long hair. Her right(?) foot is
visible above the hem or her gown with the sole turned out toward the viewer;
her left leg and foot are not visible. Her arms are extended down and to the
left; she points with both hands and extended index fingers towards the gowned figure
below.

Five female spirits appear above and to the left of the central
figure of Mirth. They are likely flying or hovering, but may also rest on a
small band of clouds. The spirit second from the right faces right with her head
turned down and to the left. The spirit is gowned and only her upper body is
visible. She may look toward the gowned figure below and to the left. Both arms are bent and
her palms are turned out toward the viewer. Her breasts are prominent.

Five female spirits appear above and to the left of the central
figure of Mirth. They are likely flying or hovering, but may also rest on a
small band of clouds. The spirit furthest right faces forward with her arms
raised at 135 degrees. Only the figure's upper body is visible. She is probably gowned; her breasts are prominent..

A gowned male spirit flies or hovers to the left of Mirth. He is
seen from behind and faces left; his torso and head are twisted back to the
right. His head is bent back and he looks up and slightly to the right towards
the female figures above. His mouth is open. The spirit's legs are bent and
spread apart with the right knee drawn up and the left leg extended to the
right. His arms are bent upward with his hands held at shoulder height; the
palms are turned out, away from the viewer with the fingers
spread.

At least three spirits fly or hover above and to the left of Mirth's
head within the halo or cloud structure. The second figure from the bottom may
be seen from behind with its right leg drawn up; the figure leans or arches to
the right. A fourth indistinct figure may appear to the right of the arc of three.
The ground below the figures is covered with grass.

component.characteristic:
Leafy vegetation appears in the lower left corner
of the design; this may represent distant trees.

component.illusobjdesc:
Regtangular shapes in the lower left corner of the image suggest a
distant building or buildings. Additional shapes in the lower right may
represent a city, including triangular spires and possibly a tower.

A distant mountain range rises above the city in the lower right corner of
the design.

Gray coloring in the sky may indicate clouds; a scalloped line below
the group of five female spirits, above and to the left of the central figure's head, suggests at least a single cloud. The halo
surrounding Mirth's head may also represent a cloud. Yellow and red washes in
the lower half of the design suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l:
Inv WBlakeBlake's signature
appears in the lower right corner.

desc.objtitle: Night Startled by the Lark, Object 2 (Butlin 543.2)

illustration.illusobjdesc:
The male personification of a lark flies on outstretched wings in the
center of the design. The figure is nude with exposed genitals. His mouth is open
and he is probably singing. The head and shoulders of the male personification of
night appear below and to the left of the lark. The figure is old with long hair
and a beard. A crenelated, castle-like structure representing night's "watch tower" is pictured
below the lark; the lower tier may suggest an outer wall. The female
personification of the dawn appears in the lower portion of the design. The figure
is gowned and faces forward with her head turned slightly to the right and her
legs extended to the left. The figure's arms are raised horizontally. She may be
flying or hovering, or possibly rests in a chariot pulled by horses. At least
three horses are pictured to the right of Dawn. Only the front-most horse runs facing right with its front right leg bent and its front
left leg extended to the right. The female personification of the earth sits on
the ground in the lower portion of the design. The figure is gowned, with large
folds of fabric (or possibly large leaves, the same color as her gown) piled to the right. She is seen from behind with her body facing
left and her head bent back. She sits with her right leg drawn up and her left leg
bent backward. Her arms are raised at approximately 45 degrees, with her left arm
resting against her left side. Grass covers the ground below the figure of earth.
Mounds or hills of indeterminate, leafy vegetation rise to her left and right. At
least twelve stars appear in the night sky at the top of the design. Three are to
the right of the lark, two are directly above the lark's head, and six(?) are to his
left; another star appears just left of the figure of dawn. A horizontal cloud
extends from the left to right margin of the design below the lark and the figure
of night. Red and yellow coloring surrounding dawn indicates sunrise.

component.illusobjdesc:
The male personification of a lark flies on outstretched wings in
the center of the design. The figure is nude with exposed genitals. His hair is
short and curly and drawn into a point at the top of his head. His mouth is open and he may be singing. A halo of soft light
surrounds his head. The figure faces forward with his legs extended to the
right; his right leg is bent back. His arms are raised at 135 degrees with the
palms turned out, away from his body, and the fingers spread.

The head and shoulders of the male personification of Night appears
below and to the left of the lark. The figure is old with long hair and a
beard. His eyes are raised and he looks up and to the right towards the
lark.

A crenelated structure representing night's "watch tower" is pictured
below the lark. The lower tier may suggest an outer wall.

The female personification of the Dawn appears in the lower left portion
of the design. The figure is gowned and faces forward with her head turned
slightly to the right and her legs extended to the left. Her hair is long and
her mouth is open. The figure's arms are raised horizontally. She may be flying
or hovering, or possibly reclining in a chariot pulled by horses. Her breasts are prominent.

At least three horses are pictured to the right of Dawn. The
foremost horse runs facing right with its front right
leg bent and its front left leg extended to the right. Its mouth is open. The next horse, slightly to the right and with its head below that of the frontmost horse, is similarly pictured. The
horses may be pulling Dawn on an indistinct chariot.

The female personification of the Earth sits or kneels on the ground in the
lower portion of the design. The figure is gowned, with large folds of fabric (or possibly large leaves colored the same as the gown)
piled to the right. She is seen from behind with her body facing left and her
head bent back. Her eyes are raised and she looks toward the figure of the
lark, above. Her hair is long. She sits or partly kneels with her right leg drawn up and her
left leg bent backward. Her arms are raised at approximately 45 degrees, with
her left arm resting against her left side. The palms on both hands are turned
out, away from her body.

Grass covers the ground below Earth. Mounds or hills of
indeterminate, leafy vegetation rise to her left and right.

At least twelve stars appear in the night sky at the top of the
design. Three are to the right of the lark, two are directly above the lark's
head, and six(?) to his left; another star appears just left of Dawn. A
horizontal cloud extends from the left to right margin of the design below the
lark and Night. Red and yellow coloring surrounding Dawn indicates
sunrise.

lg.l:
WBlakenvBlake's signature appears in the lower right corner. The first letter
of the inscription following Blake's name, almost certainly "[i]nv," has flaked
or been rubbed off the water color. Two dots just right and above the "[i]nv"
inscription might be a raised colon or the fragments of a "t" (hence,
"[i]nvt").

desc.objtitle: The Sun at His Eastern Gate, Object 3 (Butlin 543.3)

illustration.illusobjdesc:
The male personification of the sun stands in the center of the design.
The figure is nude and faces forward with his genitals exposed. His hair is
flame-like and he wears a spiky crown. Beams of light radiate outward from his
head, and his body is surrounded by an aura of flames. The figure appears to stand
with his feet raised on tiptoe; his left foot touches the central mountain in the
scene below while his right rests on the lower step of an arched structure,
possibly representing Milton's "Eastern Gate." The figure's arms are raised
horizontally. His left palm is held vertically and he holds a scepter in his right
hand. The disc of the sun surrounds the central figure. A few beams of light
radiate outward from the lower half of the sun. Blue wash surrounding the sun
indicates sky. Several clouds are visible within and around the sphere of the sun.
The figures surrounding the personification of the sun represent Milton's "Clouds
in thousand Liveries." Four trumpeters fly or hover within the lower portion of
the sun, to the left and right of the central figure. Three nude male(?) figures, possibly chilren,
stand or hover below the Sun's right arm. Each figure holds a vase or pitcher in
front of his chest. The head of a trumpeter appears just to the left of the Sun's
right hand; the figure faces slightly right and plays a trumpet or musical horn that extends
upwards and to the right from his or her mouth. A figure of indeterminate gender
flies or hovers below and to the right of the sun's left arm; the figure's arms
are bent upward and holds a plate or basket with four round fruits on top of its
head. The head and upper arms of a figure hovers just right of the sun's left
hand; the figure faces forward with its arms bent upward and its hands clutching
its head. The upper body of a female(?) figure with long hair appears above and to
the right of the sun. She faces left with her head turned back to the right; her
left arm is bent upwards with the palm turned up. The head of a female(?) figure
appears above and to the right of the sun, facing left; she may be smiling. A
bunch of fruit, possibly grapes, appears in the sky in the upper right corner of
the design. Green coloring suggests at least one leaf above the round fruit. A
nude female flies or hovers left of the disc of the sun. She is upside down and
seen from behind. Her arms are extended downward; she pours liquid from a vial or
other vessel held in her left hand. Three nude female figures fly or hover above
and to the left of the Sun. The figure furthest left is positioned with her right
leg drawn up. The figures to the right are partially obscured so that only their
heads and portions of their upper bodies are visible. Each of the three figures
holds a plate of fruit in her outstretched left hand and pours liquid from a bowl or goblet
held with the right hand. Two figures fly or hover in the upper left corner of the
image. The figures are upside down and arch or bend with their legs to the right
around the frame of the Eastern Gate. Both figures' arms extended downward. At
least nine indistinct figures fly or hover near the center of the top border of
the image. Six figures appear to the left of the plates of food, while at least
three and as many as six appear to the right. The figures appear to be gowned. The
three figures furthest left raise their right arms at 135 degrees. The ground at
the bottom of the design is covered with grass. Two leafy trees appear in the
lower left and lower right corner of the design. The trunk of the tree to the left
splits into two branches. In his description, Blake identifies the tree to the
right as a hawthorne; the tree to the left may represent an elm. An angel or other
winged spirit flies in front of a tree in the lower left corner of the design;
another angel or winged spirit flies facing left in front of the tree in the lower
right. Three mountains rise above the pastoral scene at the bottom of the design.
In the lower portion of the design, a figure pushes a plow drawn by two horned oxen.
The figure is bent forward and walks to the right. A female(?) figure stands to
the right of the plow in the lower portion of the design; this figure may
represent Milton's "Milkmaid." A horned cow lies near the milkmaid, facing left; another lies to the right, facing right. A
figure stands to the right of the milkmaid in the lower portion of the design. The
figure's right arm is raised horizontally and holds an indeterminate curved object
above its head. This may represent Milton's "Mower," which would suggest that the
object is his scythe. A solitary gowned figure stands on a small hillock to the
right of the mower. Blake's notes suggest that this may represent Milton. Two
gowned figures stand beneath a tree in the lower right corner of the design.
According to Blake's description, they likely represent "the Shepherd" and "his
Lass." The figures appear to face each other. Two winged angels stand on the lower
step of the Eastern Gate to the left and right of the sphere of the sun. Both are
gowned and hold trumpets or musical horns at their sides.

component.illusobjdesc:
The male personification of the sun stands in the center of the
design. The figure is nude and faces forward with his genitals exposed. His
hair is flame-like and he wears a spiky crown. Beams of light radiate outward
from his head, and his body is surrounded by an aura of flames. The figure
appears to stand with his feet raised on tiptoe; his left foot touches the
central mountain in the scene below while his right rests on the lower step of
an arched structure, possibly representing Milton's "Eastern Gate." The Sun's
arms are raised horizontally. His left palm is held vertically while in his
right hand he holds a scepter with a fleur-de-lis finial.

The personification of the sun stands with his right foot on the
lower step of an arched structure, likely representing Milton's "Eastern Gate."
The gate is largely obscured by the disc of the sun and surrounding figures,
but is visible in the lower and upper corners of the design.

The disc of the sun surrounds the figure in the center of the
design. A few beams of light radiate outward from the lower half of the
sun.

Blue wash surrounding the sun indicates sky. Several clouds are
visible within and around the sphere of the sun. The figures surrounding the
personification of the Sun represent Milton's "Clouds in thousand
Liveries."

Two gowned trumpeters fly or hover within the lower left portion of
the sun on the left. The figures face left with their heads turned upward. A halo with spiky beams of light surrounds
each figure's head. Their arms are raised vertically and they each hold a
trumpet in their right hand. The figure on the right has long hair. The figure
on the left is partially obscured by a cloud.

Two trumpeters fly or hover within the lower right portion of the
sun on the right. The figures face right with their heads turned upward. Only the figures'
heads and upper bodies are visible. Their arms are raised vertically and they
each hold a trumpet or musical horn in their left hand.

Three nude male(?) figures, possibly children, stand or hover below the personified Sun's right arm.
Each figure has short, curly hair. They face forward with their heads turned to
the right. A halo may surround each figure's head; alternatively, these halos
may represent clouds. Each figure holds a vase or pitcher in front of his
chest. The figure furthest left holds a vase or pitcher with a clearly visible
handle.

The head of a trumpeter appears just to the left of the Sun's right
hand. The figure faces slightly right and plays a trumpet or musical horn that extends upwards
and to the right from his or her mouth. Curved lines below the trumpet
indicate the figure's left arm and hand, raised vertically.

A figure of indeterminate gender flies or hovers below and to the
right of the Sun's left arm. The figure appears to be nude, though there is the
suggestion of a shirt collar around the figure's neck. The figure faces forward
with his or her head turned slightly left. His or her right leg is drawn up
while the left leg extends down and to the left. The figure's arms are bent
upward and holds a plate or basket with four round fruits on top of his or her
head.

The head and upper arms of a figure hovers just right of the Sun's
left hand. The figure faces forward with its arms bent upward and its hands
clutching its head. Flame-like locks of hair surmount his or her head.

The upper body of a female(?) figure with long hair appears above
and to the right of the sun; she may be hovering or flying. The figure faces
left with her head turned back to the right; the figure's eyes are raised and
her mouth is open. Her left arm is bent upwards with the palm turned
up.

The head of a female(?) figure appears above and to the right of the
sun, facing left; she may be flying or hovering. The figure appears to be
smiling. Her right arm is raised and bent over her head; she may be holding the vegetation trailing above her back.

A bunch of fruit, possibly grapes, appears in the sky in the upper
right corner of the design. Green coloring suggests at least one leaf above the
round fruit. This may be a vine or garland held by the figure just below.

Three nude female figures fly or hover above and to the left of the
Sun. The figures face forward with their heads turned up and to the right and
their eyes raised. The figure furthest left has long hair, and her mouth may be
open. Her right leg is drawn up. The figures to the right are partially
obscured so that only their heads and portions of their upper bodies are
visible. All three figures raise their left arms at 135 degrees and each holds
a plate of round fruit. Several leaves are also pictured on the uppermost
plate. Perhaps the rounded object on this plate is a loaf of bread. The leftmost figure raises her right arm at 45 degrees; the other
figures' right arms are raised horizontally. Each figure pours liquid from a
bowl or goblet held in their right hands.

A nude female flies or hovers left of the disc of the sun. She is
upside down and seen from behind. Her hair is long and her eyes may be closed
or cast down. At least her left arm is extended downward. She pours liquid from a vial or
other vessel held in her left hand.

At least nine indistinct figures fly or hover near the center of the
top border of the image. Six figures appear to the left of the plates of food,
while at least three and as many as six appear to the right. The figures appear
to be gowned. The three figures furthest left raise their right arms at 135
degrees. A few curving lines to the left of the group may suggest more figures.

Two figures fly or hover in the upper left corner of the image. The
figures are upside down and arch or bend with their legs to the right around
the frame of the Eastern Gate. Both figures' arms extend
downward.

The ground at the bottom of the design is covered with grass.
Several figures stand on small mounds or hillocks.

Two leafy trees appear in the lower left and lower right corner of
the design. The trunk of the tree to the left splits into two branches. In his
description, Blake identifies the tree to the right as a hawthorne; the tree to
the left may represent an elm.

Three mountains rise above the pastoral scene at the bottom of the
design.

An angel or other winged spirit appears in front of a tree in the
lower left corner of the design. The figure flies facing right with its arm
extended to the right.

An angel or other winged spirit appears in front of a tree in the
lower right corner of the design. The figure flies facing left.

In the lower portion of the design, a figure pushes a plow drawn by
two horned oxen. The figure is bent forward and walks to the right.

A female(?) figure stands or walks, probably facing right, to the right of the plow in the lower
portion of the design. This figure may represent Milton's
"Milkmaid."
A horned cow lies near the milkmaid, facing left. Another lies on the ground to the right, facing right.

A figure stands or walks to the right of the milkmaid in the lower portion of
the design. The figure's right arm is raised horizontally and holds an
indeterminate curved object above its head. This may represent Milton's
"Mower," which would suggest that the object is his scythe.

A solitary gowned figure, probably facing forward, stands on a small hillock to the right of
the mower. Blake's notes suggest that this may represent Milton.

Two gowned figures stand beneath a tree in the lower right corner of
the design. According to Blake's description, they likely represent "the
Shepherd" and "his Lass." The figures appear to face each other.

Indistinct shapes right of the plowman suggest a distant building or buildings
with a column of smoke rising above one structure.

A winged angel stands on the lower step of the Eastern Gate, just to
the right of the tree in the lower left corner of the design. The figure is
gowned and has long hair. A halo of light surrounds its head. The angel stands
facing forward with its head turned slightly to the right. The figure's left
arm is raised at 45 degrees and holds a trumpet or musical horn in its left
hand.

A winged angel stands on the lower step of the Eastern Gate, just to
the left of the tree in the lower right corner of the design. The figure is
gowned and has short, possibly curly hair. A halo of light surrounds its head.
The angel stands facing forward with its head turned slightly to the left. The
figure's right arm is raised at 45 degrees and holds a trumpet or musical horn in its right
hand.

lg.l:
WBlake invBlake's signature appears in
the lower left corner. The lower parts of the letters have been trimmed off the
paper.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
A personified female mountain sits the center of the design with her
legs bent beneath her. She is nude and wears a crown. A cascade of water, perhaps a waterfall that extends into a river, descends from her left shoulder. A walled(?) city appears in
her lap. Several windows are visible in the lower right portion of the wall and
two tall spires rise above the wall. The head and left shoulder of a male mountain
appear to the right of the female mountain. He has a beard and wears a crown of
leaves. A house with a sloping roof and a window or door stands below the male
mountain. Below the house is a winding path or road. Above the mountains, beams of
light radiate outward from the sun. A horizontal band of clouds appears across the
chests of the male and female mountains; at least seventeen figures representing
personified clouds appear in the sky above and to the left and right of the
mountains. Several of these figures hold objects, including trumpets or musical horns, tambourines,
vases or urns, and a basket. Two gowned angels also appear in the sky to
the left and right of the mountains; both play (or at least hold) trumpets or musical horns. Two figures lay or
recline on a mountain or hill to the left of the personified female mountain. The figure on
the right side of the mountain is a nude female with her breasts exposed. Below
and to the left, a second figure reclines at the base of the mountain, on the
shore of a lake. The female personification of a river appears below and
to the right of the female mountain. The female river holds a goblet or chalice in
her left hand; her head is bent back as she drinks from the cup. She leans to the
right against a vase or other vessel; water pours into the river below. The river
extends horizontally across the design and empties into a lake at the left border
of the image. Several long, rectangular buildings appear to the left of the
personified river. The building furthest left has a clearly defined roof. The
roofs of two buildings are visible below the personified river; there may be another building right of her right hand. The spire of a
Gothic church rises above a forest of trees at the left border of the design. The
top of an arched window is visible just above the tree line. The forest of leafy
trees extends from the left to the right border in the lower portion of the design.
The trunks and branches of several trees are clearly visible. The head and right
arm of a male figure appear among the leaves of a tree in the lower right portion
of the image; the figure represents the personification of the tree. His hair is
long and he has a beard. Three spirits fly or hover to the right of the tree. The
two uppermost spirits play trumpets; the third spirit has butterfly wings. A group
of eight figures stand below the personified tree; they may represent a family.
From left to right, the family includes: a young boy playing a pipe; a gowned
female cradling an infant in her arms; a gowned child; an old gowned female with a
walking stick in her right hand; an old bearded male with a walking stick in his
left hand; and two gowned children. A pole stands in the lower portion of the
design, slightly left of center. Two triangles are formed near the top of the pole
by a crossbeam or circular structure and thin lines decorated with flowers or fruit. This likely
represents a maypole. A male musician stands directly below the maypole; he plays
a violin or fiddle. At least seven other figures dance to the left and right with
their arms raised at 135 degrees. Most hold the raised hands of their companions. The ground below the figures is covered with
grass.

component.illusobjdesc:
A personified female mountain sits or kneels in the center of the design with her
legs bent beneath her. Her body faces slightly left and her head is turned to
face forward. She is nude and wears a crown resembling a crenelated wall. Her left arm is bent and
her left hand rests on her left breast with the fingers spread. Her right arm
rests at her side and dangles over her lap. A cascade of water, perhaps a waterfall that becomes a river, descends from her left shoulder. Perhaps this is also meant to be an extension of her long hair or a cloth over her shoulder.

The head and left shoulder of a male mountain appears to the right
of the female mountain. The figure has a beard and wears a crown of leaves. His
mouth may be open. His right hand touches or holds the right shoulder of the
female mountain.

A walled(?) city appears in the lap of the female mountain. Several
windows are visible in the lower right portion of the wall. Two tall spires
rise above the wall.

A house with a sloping roof stands below the male mountain. A single
window or door is visible. Below the house is a winding path or
road.

Blue wash indicates sky. Above the mountains, beams of light radiate
outward from the sun. A horizontal band of clouds appears across the upper chests of
the male and female mountains.

At least fourteen gowned spirits representing clouds fly or hover
above and to the left of the female mountain. The figures may be rising into
the air. The two uppermost figures (above the head of the male mountain) face
to the right with their bodies nearly horizontal. To the left, a figure flies
with his or her arms raised at 135 degrees; the figure holds two circular
objects, likely tambourines. To the left, two figures hold an urn or vase with
two curved handles. The figure to the right of the urn bends at the waist and
may face to the left; the figure to the left has its right leg slightly bent.
To the left, two figures hold and play trumpets or musical horns. The uppermost trumpeter bends
his or her head back. To the left, two figures hold an urn or vase with two
curved handles. The figure right of the urn arches his or her back and may
twist its upper body to face to the left. Below, a figure bends his or her arms
upward and holds a large wicker basket above its head. The figure may be seen
from behind. Below and to the right, two figures fly facing left. The
rightmost figure of the pair holds a bowl with his or her left arm; the bowl
appears to contain one or two large, round fruits. the next figure to the right is represented by the outline of its head and one shoulder. To the right, and closest to the personified female mountain, a figure is
seen from behind with its left arm bent upwards. At least three additional
spirits fly to the right of the male mountain.

A gowned female angel flies or hovers in the upper left corner of
the design, facing left. Her left arm is bent and her right is extended down
and to the left; she holds a trumpet or musical horn with both hands. Although the trumpet does not seem to touch her mouth, she may be playing the instrument. Her hair is long and her
mouth is open. A halo of light surrounds her head. One or two lines behind her back may be strands of long hair.

A gowned female(?) angel flies or hovers in the upper right corner
of the design. She is seen from behind and faces away and to the right. Her
right arm is extended down and to the right; she holds and may play a trumpet or musical horn.
Her hair is long and a halo of light surrounds her head.

Two figures lay or recline on a mountain or hill to the left of the
female mountain. The figure to the right is a nude female with her breasts
exposed. She leans against her bent right arm and faces right. Below and to the
left, a second figure reclines at the base of the mountain, on the shore of a
lake or river. The figure faces forward with his or her body horizontal and
legs extended to the left. The figure's left arm is bent and rests on the
ground.

The female personification of a river appears below and to the right
of the female mountain. The female figure is nude and rests with her right leg
bent to the left; her left leg is not pictured below the knee and may be
submerged in the river. Her hips and legs face forward with her upper body
twisted to the right. Her hair is long. Her left arm is bent upward and she
holds a goblet or chalice in her left hand; her head is bent back as she drinks
from the cup. She leans to the right against a vase or other vessel that pours
water into the river below. The river extends horizontally across the design
and empties into a lake at the left border of the image.

At least two or three long, rectangular buildings appear to the left of the
personified river. The building furthest left has a clearly defined
roof.

The roofs and chimneys of two buildings, possibly cottages, are visible below the personified
river.

The spire of a Gothic church rises above a forest of trees at the
left border of the design. The top of an arched window is visible just above
the tree line.

A forest of leafy trees extends from the left to right border in the
lower portion of the design. The trunks and branches of several trees are
clearly visible.

The head and right arm of a male figure appear among the leaves of a
tree in the lower right portion of the image; the figure is a
personification of the trees. He faces left with his head tilted slightly down.
He may look towards the figures below. His hair is long and he has a beard. His
right arm, partially obscured by leaves, is bent upward. The fingers on his
right hand are spread, and he points upward.

A spirit flies or hovers to the right of the personified Tree. The
figure is seen from behind and faces away with his or her head turned slightly
to the right. The figure is nude. The figure's left leg is extened to the
right; the right leg is not visible. The figure's right arm extends to the
right, and he or she appears to hold and play a trumpet or musical horn.

A gowned(?) spirit flies or hovers above and to the right of the
personified Tree; the figure may be rising. The spirit is seen from behind with
his or her arms raised vertically; the figure holds and plays a trumpet (or musical horn) above
his or her head.

A spirit with butterfly wings flies below and to the right of the
personified Tree; the figure may be rising. The figure is seen from behind and
faces slightly left. The figure is nude. Both legs are bent; the right leg
appears to be drawn up, with the right knee pointing to the
left.

A circular bench or seat around the tree, or possibly a table or stool with one visible leg, appears in the lower right
corner of the design, below the trunk of the personified Tree.

The group of eight figures below the personified tree may represent
a family.

A gowned child of indeterminate gender stands in the lower right
corner of the design, facing left. The child may have long hair. His or her
head is turned up, and the child may look at the butterfly-winged spirit above.
The figure's left arm is bent upwards, and may touch or hold the left arm of
the figure to the left.

A gowned child of indeterminate gender stands in the lower right
corner of the design. The figure faces forward with his or her head turned to
the right. The child's mouth may be open. The figure's left arm is down at its
side. His or her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and may touch the left hand
of the figure to the left.

An old man stands, slightly leaning over, in the lower right portion of the
design. His legs are slightly bent. His left arm is bent and he leans upon the
walking stick or crutch held in his left hand. His right arm is bent across his chest;
the woman to the left rests her left hand in the crook of his elbow. The figure
has long hair and a beard. He wears a gown.

A gowned female stands in the lower right portion of the design. She
faces forward and slightly left. She wears a cloth scarf or other drapery on
her head. Her left hand rests on the elbow of the male figure to the right; her
left arm is not visible. Her right arm is down at her side and she holds a
walking stick or crutch in her right hand.

A gowned child of indeterminate gender stands in the lower right
portion of the design. He or she is partially obscured by the adult figures left and
right. The child faces forward with his or her head turned to the right. The
child's eyes are raised; he or she may look toward the old woman above and
to the right.

A gowned female stands in the lower portion of the design. Her arms
are bent and crossed in front of her chest; she holds an infant with her
prominent right hand. She faces forward with her head turned slightly to the
right. Her eyes are cast down and she looks at the infant in her
arms.

A female holds an infant of indeterminate gender in the lower
portion of the design. The infant lays facing up with its body horizontal and
its legs extended to the left. The infant's left arm is bent, and his or her
hand may touch the chest of the woman.

A male child stands in the lower portion of the design, just left of
the woman holding an infant. The child faces forward and slightly left. His
left leg is bent and his left foot is raised on tiptoe. He wears tights and a
shirt, and may also wear shoes. His arms are bent; he holds and plays a pipe or musical horn
with both hands.

A large shadow appears on the ground below the family, extending
from approximately the center of the design to the right border.

A pole stands in the lower portion of the design, slightly left of
center. Two triangles are formed near the top of the pole by a crossbeam (or a circular object) and
thin lines decorated with flowers or fruit. This likely represents a maypole. A
group of eight figures appears to the left and right of the
maypole.

Eight figures appear left and right of the maypole in the lower
portion of the design. A gowned female dances on tiptoe furthest left. She faces forward
with her head turned slightly right. She may be smiling. Her legs are crossed
at the ankle with her left leg prominent; both feet are raised on tiptoe. The
figure's left arm is raised at 135 degrees with the palm held vertically; she
touches (perhaps holds) the left hand of the figure to the right.

Eight figures appear left and right of the maypole in the lower
portion of the design. A male with short, curly hair dances on tiptoe second from the
left. He is seen from behind with his head turned to the right; he may look
towards the female just left of the pole. The male dancer wears a coat and
breeches with stockings and shoes. His legs are crossed at the knees with the left
leg extended backward; both feet are raised on tiptoe. His arms are raised at
135 degrees with the palms held vertically; his hands touch (perhaps hold) those of two female
dancers to the left and right.

Eight figures appear left and right of the maypole in the lower
portion of the design. A gowned female dances third from the left. She faces
forward with her head turned slightly left. The figure's right arm is bent; her
right hand is not visible. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees with the palm
turned up. Both feet are visible below the hem of her gown and are raised on
tiptoe.

Eight figures appear left and right of the maypole in the lower
portion of the design. A gowned gemale dances fourth from the left. Both feet
are raised on tiptoe and she appears to wear shoes. She faces forward with her
head turned slightly left. She looks toward the male figure to the left. Both
arms are raised at 135 degrees. Her right palm is held vertically and touches (perhaps holds)
the right palm of the male dancer. Her left hand is raised with the palm turned
up.

Eight figures appear left and right of the maypole in the lower
portion of the design. A male musician stands fifth from the left. He wears a
long coat, possibly breeches, stockings, and shoes. His left foot is raised on tiptoe
and he may walk to the right. His body faces to the right with his head turned
back to the left; he may look toward he group of dancers. His right arm is bent
across his body; his left arm is not visible. The figure plays a violin or
fiddle; he holds the instrument against his left shoulder with his left hand
and grips the bow with his right hand.

Eight figures appear left and right of the maypole in the lower
portion of the design. A gowned female dances sixth from the left. She is seen
from behind and faces away with her head turned to the right. Her hair is drawn
back in a bun. The figure's arms are raised at 135 degrees with the palms held
vertically; she may touch the palm of the figure to the right. He head may rest
on her right shoulder. The figure's right foot is raised on tiptoe; her left
leg extends backward and to the right.

Eight figures appear left and right of the maypole in the lower
portion of the design. A gowned female appears seventh from the left; she is
partially obscured by the figure below and to the right. The figure faces
forward with her head bent to the left. She appears to be smiling. Her left arm
is raised at 135 degrees and may touch or hold the hands of her nearest companions; her right arm is not visible. She may be
dancing.

component.characteristic:
Eight figures appear left and right of the maypole in the lower
portion of the design. The head, left shoulder and left arm of a figure appear
eighth from the left. The figure is featureless and is partially obscured by
the personified tree to the right and the child below. The figure's head may
rest on its shoulder. Its left arm is raised at 135 degrees with the palm held
vertically; it may touch or hold the palm of the figure to the left. The figure's right
arm(?) may also be raised above his or her head. The figure may be
dancing.

component.illusobjdesc:
The ground below the group of dancers and the family to the right is
covered with grass.

lg.l:
WBlake invBlake's signature
appears in the lower right corner. The lower parts of the letters have been
trimmed off the paper.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
A nude male spirit flies or hover in the center of the design. This
represents Milton's "Goblin." The figure is partially transparent. The goblin is
twisted with his arms and legs extended to the right. He drops a flail and a large
bowl from his raised hands. A gowned female sits on a raised platform in the upper
left potion of the design. She is identified by Blake in his description of the design as Queen Mab. She is
surrounded by an aura of light and she may wear a crown. Her left arm is bent and
she may reach towards the plate of food to the right. Her right arm is bent
upwards and she holds a cup or possibly food in her right hand. A gowned spirit
flies or hovers to the right of Mab. The figure holds a plate of
food—possibly fruit—above his or her head. The scene takes place
at night. A cloud band passes across the goblin's hips, while another appears
above and to the right of the goblin's head. At least twenty stars appear in the
sky, five of which appear on or through the goblin's body. Perhaps two more
indistinct stars appear to the left and right of the flail, although it is difficult to distingish these from abraded areas on the design. A house or cottage
stands in the lower left corner of the design. The building has a roof, probably of straw,
and a chimney. The wall facing the viewer is transparent to reveal the room
within. A window with two panes is also visible. A female lies supine on a bed
within the cottage. Her head rests on a pillow to the left, and her body is
covered by bed linens. She grasps her head with her hands; her mouth may be open in an expression of fear. The head and shoulders of a ghost appear above and to the
right of the bed. The ghost faces left with its arms extended down and to the
left; it holds and pulls the bedclothes. Four nude fairies appear in the cottage
in the lower left corner of the design; they may be dancing. The lowest fairy
appears to reach upward and may be climbing onto the bed below the female figure.
Another fairy stands above the bed and lunges to the right. Two
additional fairies appear upside down on the ceiling of the room. A building
stands in the lower right corner of the design. It may represent a barn or stable.
A large door with clearly visible hinges faces the viewer. A male figure appears
between the two buildings in the lower portion of the design. He is seen from
behind and faces away with his head turned to the right. He bends slightly forward with
both legs bent and his left foot raised on tiptoe; he is walking and follows the
spirit to the right. A friar, possibly holding a lantern, appears between the two buildings in the lower portion of the
design. He is seen from behind and faces to the right with his head turned back to
the left; he may look at the figure to the left. The friar's lower half is
obscured. A distant building is visible on a hill or cliff above the the male
figure and the friar. This may represent the "Convent" mentioned in
Blake's description. The structure has an outer wall with two towers flanking an arched
entryway. The tower on the left is topped with a spire. A dark mass above and to
the right of the convent may represent a distant forest of leafy trees. The ground just above the lower border of the design is grassy.

component.illusobjdesc:
A nude male spirit flies or hover in the center of the design. This
represents Milton's "Goblin." The figure is partially transparent. His left leg
is bent to the right with his right leg extended downward. His torso is twisted
to face forward with his head turned slightly to the right. The goblin's eyes
are raised and his mouth is open with the teeth visible; Blake indicates that
the goblin is yawning. The figure may be bald and may have multiple pairs of horns.
His right arm is bent upward with the palm turned down; his left arm is raised
at 135 degrees with the palm held nearly vertically. The fingers on both hands
are spread. The goblin drops a flail and a large bowl.

The goblin drops a flail and large bowl from his raised
hands.

A gowned female sits on a raised platform in the upper left potion
of the design. She is identified by Blake as Queen Mab. She is surrounded by an
aura of radiance and she may wear a crown. Her left arm is bent and she
may reach towards the plate of food to the right. Her right arm is bent upwards
and she holds a bowl or possibly food in her right hand. She is described in
Milton's poem as eating "junkets."
Mab sits on a plinth-like series of stairs or steps.

A gowned spirit flies or hovers to the right of Mab. The figure may
be seen from behind. His or her legs are extended slightly to the right. The
spirit's arms are bent upward. The figure holds a plate of
food—possibly fruit and a bottle—above his or her head.

The scene takes place at night. A thin cloud passes across the
goblin's hips, while another appears above and to the right of the goblin's
head. At least twenty stars appear in the sky, five of which appear on or
through the goblin's body. Perhaps two more indistinct stars appear to the left
and right of the flail, although these are not easily distinguished from the abraded patches in this area.

A house or cottage stands in the lower left corner of the design.
The building has a roof, probably of straw, and a chimney. The wall facing the viewer is
transparent to reveal the room within. A window with two distinct panes is also
visible.

A female (so identified in Blake's description of the design) lies supine on a bed within the cottage. Her head rests on
a pillow to the left, and her body is covered by bed linens or a blanket to the right. Her arms are raised to grasp her head; her mouth may be open in an expression of fear. She may be looking at the figure standing at her feet.

A female lies on a bed within the cottage. A pillow is visible to
the left of the figure's head, and a blanket or other bedclothes cover her
body.

The head and shoulders of a figure appear above and to the right of
the bed. Blake identifies the figure as a ghost. Horizontal lines through the figure suggest that the ghost is transparent. The ghost may have long hair
or possibly wears a scarf or other cloth over its head. The figure faces left
with its arms extended down and to the left. The ghost holds and perhaps pulls at the
bedclothes.

Four nude fairies appear in the cottage in the lower left corner of
the design. The lowest figure is seen from behind. It stands on the floor of
the room with its right left drawn up. Its arms are raised at 135 degrees and
it may be reaching towards the figure above. The fairy's head appears to be
turned up. The figure may be dancing or possibly climbing onto the
bed.

Four nude fairies appear in the cottage in the lower left corner of
the design. A fairy hovers upside down directly above the female figure's head.
Its body faces to the right with its head turned forward towards the viewer.
The figure's left leg is bent with its left foot raised on tiptoe; the right
leg is extended to the right. The fairy's left arm is bent upward and wrapped
around its head; the right arm is raised at 135 degrees relative to the body.
Blake indicates that the figure is dancing.

Four nude fairies appear in the cottage in the lower left corner of
the design. One spirit stands above the bedclothes, just right of the
female figure's head. The figure appears to lunge to the right; its left leg is
bent forward (to the right) while the right leg is bent backward (to the left).
The figure's back is arched and the head may be bent back. Both arms are raised
at 135 degrees and extend up and to the right. Blake indicates that the figure
is dancing.

Four nude fairies appear in the cottage in the lower left corner of
the design. The spirit furthest right hovers upside down near above the foot of
the bed. The figure faces right with its arms raised horizontally. The fairy's
left leg is bent forward (to the right) while its left leg is bent backward (to
the left). Blake indicates that the figure is dancing.

A male figure appears between the two buildings in the lower portion
of the design. He is seen from behind and faces away with his head turned to
the right. He bends forward slightly with both legs bent and his left foot raised on
tiptoe; he is walking and follows the spirit to the right. The figure's arms
are down at his sides with the palms turned down. He wears breeches and a shirt
with slight indications of a belt at his waist. He also appears to wear
stockings and shoes. A hat covers his long hair.

A figure, identified in the poem as a friar, appears between the two buildings in the lower portion of the design.
He is seen from behind and faces to the right with his head turned back to the
left. He may look at the figure to the left. The friar is gowned and has long
hair. He bends slightly right at the waist. His right arm is down at his side;
the left arm is not pictured. The friar's lower half is
obscured, but he may holding a latern in his right hand.

A (wooden?) building stands in the lower right corner of the design. It may
represent a barn or stable. A large door with clearly visible hinges faces the
viewer.

A distant building is visible on a hill or cliff above the the male
figure and the friar. This may represent the "Convent" mentioned in
Blake's description of the design. The structure has an outer wall with two towers flanking an
arched entryway. The tower on the left is topped with a spire.

A dark mass above and to the right of the convent may represent a
distant forest of leafy trees.

The convent appears on a dark hill or at the edge of a
cliff.

The ground below the cottage and stable is covered with
grass.

lg.l:
WBlake invBlake's signature
appears in the lower right corner.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
A young male poet representing Milton reclines on the bank of a stream
or river. He rests on a small hill or hillock covered with grass. His head is bent
back with his eyes closed; the poet is sleeping and dreaming. His head is
surrounded by a dark halo. Milton's right arm rests on a book to the left; he
holds a quill or pen in his right hand and he may be writing. The sun sets in the
sky to the left of Milton. Two trees grow to the left and right of the poet along
the vertical edges of the design. Both have distinct roots, trunks, and leaves.
The tree to the right also has disctinct branches. The leaves of both trees arch
up and towards the center of the upper border. A small nude(?) figure appears below
and to the left of Milton. The figure walks or strides to the left with its legs
spread apart. The figure's arms are raised at 135 degrees with the palms turned
up. Two gowned figures stand embracing in the lower left corner of the design. The
figure on the right has his or her head down and resting on the right shoulder of
the figure to the left. Three gowned females fly or hover in the lower right
portion of the design. They may represent ghosts. Two gowned males representing
Jonson ("Johnson" in Blake's description of the design) and Shakespeare hover in the upper portion of the design, above Milton.
The figure to the left (probably Jonson) faces right and holds an open book and quill pen. The
figure to the right (probably Shakespeare) faces forward and holds a set of pipes. Beams of light emanate from both figures' heads. A large circle
representing the "Sun of Imagination" appears in the sky between Jonson and
Shakespeare. Beams of light radiate outward from the lower half of the sun. As
many as eighteen figures appear within the circle of the sun; the figures are
surrounded by flames and possibly smoke. In the top center of the sun, Hymen
stands between a bride (left) and groom (right). Hymen is gowned and a halo of
light surrounds his head. He may hold hands with the bride and groom. Six
indistinct gowned figures stand to the left and right. Three female musicians
stand below the marriage scene. The figure furthest left is seen from behind; she
holds and may play a harp or lyre. The central figure faces forward and holds two trumpets or musical horns
in her hands. The figure furthest right holds and may play a tambourine. As many as
six indistinct figures hover above the flames to the left and right of the
musicians.

component.illusobjdesc:
A young male poet representing Milton reclines on the bank of a
stream or river. His body is supine with his legs extended down and to the
left. He wears a shirt with an elaborate ruffled collar, breeches,
and shoes. Milton's right arm rests on an open book to the left. He holds a
quill or pen in his right hand; he may be writing. Milton's left arm is bent
upward with the palm turned out towards the viewer and the fingers slightly
spread. His head is bent back and his eyes closed; the poet is sleeping and
dreaming. He may be smiling. Milton has long, curly hair and his head is
surrounded by a dark halo.

An open book lies on the ground to the left of Milton. Milton holds
a quill or pen in his right hand and may write upon the page of the
book.
The sun sets in the sky to the left of Milton.

Milton rests on a small hill or hillock covered with grass. Two
trees grow to the left and right of the poet along the vertical edges of the
design. Both have distinct roots, trunks, and leaves. The tree to the right
also has disctinct branches. The leaves of both trees arch up and towards the
center of the upper border.

component.characteristic:
A river or stream runs horizontally across the lower portion of
the design, below Milton. The river bank just above the lower border of the design may be sand without vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc:
A small nude(?) figure appears below and to the left of Milton. The
figure walks or strides to the left with its legs spread apart. The figure
faces left, but its head may be turned back to the right. The figure's arms are raised at 135 degrees with the
palms turned up.

Two gowned figures stand embracing in the lower left corner of the
design. The figure on the left faces right and the figure on the right faces
left. The rightmost figure's head is down and rests on the right shoulder of
the figure to the left.

Three gowned females fly or hover in the lower right portion of the
design. They may represent ghosts appearing near Milton's "haunted Stream." The
figure furthest left faces left with her head turned to the right. She has long
hair and her mouth is open. The figure's arms are bent upward on either side of
her body; her right palm is held vertically and faces left.

Three gowned females fly or hover in the lower right portion of the
design. The central figure faces left with her head turned to face forward. She
has long hair and her mouth is open. The figure's arms are down at her sides
with the palms turned down.

Three gowned females fly or hover in the lower right portion of the
design. The figure furthest left faces left with her head and torso turned to
the right. She has long hair and her mouth is open. The figure's arms are
raised upwards; both palms are held vertically and face out to the
right.

A gowned male probably representing Ben Jonson ("Johnson" in Blake's description of the design) hovers in
the upper left portion of the design, facing right. Both Jonson and Shakespeare are named in Milton's poem. Since the figure on the right is probably Shakespeare (see description below), this figure on the left is probably Jonson. The figure has short curly
hair and a beard. Beams of light emanate from his head. Both feet are visible
below the hem of his garment. The figure's right arm is bent and he holds a
quill in his right hand; in his left hand he holds an open book.

A gowned male probably representing William Shakespeare hovers in
the upper right portion of the design. In his poem, Milton describes Shakespeare as as the poet who "warble[s] his native Wood-notes wild," and thus he is probably this figure, holding musical pipes. He faces forward and looks out toward
the viewer. The figure has short hair and a beard. Beams of light emanate from
his head. The figure's mouth is open and he may be speaking. His right arm is
bent across his chest and he holds the set of pipes in his right hand. His left
hand is raised with the palm turned slightly up.

A large circle representing the "Sun of Imagination" appears in the
sky above Milton. Beams of light radiate outward from the lower half of the
sun. As many as eighteen figures appear within the circle of the sun; the
figures are surrounded by flames and possibly smoke.

A gowned male stands in the upper portion of the Sun of Imagination
facing forward. He represents Hymen, the god of marriage. A halo of light
surrounds his head. The figure's arms are at his sides, and he may touch or
hold hands with the female to the left and the male to the
right.

A female bride stands in the upper portion of the Sun of Imagination
facing right. She is gowned and wears a veil over her hair. Her right arm is
bent and she may touch or hold hands with Hymen.

A male groom stands in the upper portion of the Sun of Imagination
facing left. He has short, curly hair and may wear pants or breeches. His left
arm is bent and his right arm is down at his side; he may touch or hold hands
with Hymen. The figure's right leg is slightly bent.

Six indistinct gowned figures stand in the upper portion of the Sun
of Imagination. Three appear to the left of the bride and three are visible to
the right of the groom.

Hymen, the bride and groom, and the six indistinct figures in the
upper portion of the Sun of Imagination stand atop a series or steps or stairs.
This may represent an altar or plinth.

Three gowned female musicians stand in the lower portion of the Sun
of Imagination. Each has a halo of light surrounding her head. The musician
furthest left is seen from behind. Her hair may be drawn back into a bun. Her
left leg is bent slightly and extends to the right; her left foot is raised on
tiptoe. Her lower body faces to the left with her torso twisted to face right.
Her right arm is bent; she holds and possibly plays a harp or lyre with her right
hand.

Three gowned female musicians stand in the lower portion of the Sun
of Imagination. Each has a halo of light surrounding her head. The central
musician faces forward. Her long hair is visible above her shoulders. The
figure's arms are at her side; she holds two long trumpets or musical horns in her
hands.

Three gowned female musicians stand in the lower portion of the Sun
of Imagination. Each has a halo of light surrounding her head. The musician
furthest right stands with her body facing right and her head turned back to
the right. Her right leg is bent and extends slightly to the left; her right
foot may be raised on tiptoe. The figure has long hair. Her right arm is bent;
she holds and possibly plays a tambourine with her right hand.

Indistinct figures—perhaps six in total—are
pictured to the left and right of the female musicians. The figures may be
flying or hovering, and appear to rise above the flames.
